proxyLocation: center-left of the desk, sitting upright
utilizationMethod: Pinch the crumpled wad between thumb and the first two fingers, then perform the same wrist-flick and forearm arcs used for light hammer taps. Although the tissue is almost weightless, the irregular bulk gives a clear contact point that can be bounced against the tabletop to supply a subtle stop cue, supporting the rhythmic ‘tap-tap-tap’ motion associated with setting a nail.

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: The hammer should convey significant weight concentrated in the metal head, creating a distinctly top-heavy feel. Users would expect substantial resistance when lifting and notable momentum during swinging motions.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will perform a power-grip around the cylindrical handle, wrapping the thumb and all fingers to stabilize the top-heavy mass of the metal head. Typical motions involve raising the forearm and cocking the wrist, then executing an arcing swing that pivots at the elbow and shoulder to deliver impact with the flat striking face. Quick wrist rotations may be added for small taps or nail-setting. During the upswing the user feels inertial lag from the heavy head; during the downswing the head accelerates, amplifying momentum until contact is made with the target surface. On impact, a solid, sharp stop is expected, with vibration propagating back through the rigid handle. If the user adjusts grip toward the head (choking up), finer control and reduced torque are achieved, whereas holding the handle’s end maximizes striking force. Two-handed swings are plausible for heavier blows, requiring interleaved hand placement and full-body trunk rotation.

proxyLocation: top-left of the image, edge of the desk
utilizationMethod: Grip one of the short ends of the box with a power-grip so that most of the box’s mass extends beyond the hand. This makes the far end act like a hammer head while the gripped end serves as a makeshift handle. Swing the wrist and elbow in an arc and let the inertia of the loosely packed tissues give delayed follow-through, imitating the top-heavy lag of a real hammer head. Bringing the box down onto the desk provides a soft but sudden stop that echoes the moment of impact.

proxyLocation: upper-center of the image, lying horizontally
utilizationMethod: Hold the pen close to its clip end so that the opposite, slightly heavier cartridge end projects outward. The cylindrical barrel lets the user apply a true hammer power-grip. Swinging from the elbow gives a scaled-down but familiar feeling of directing a weighted tip toward a target surface; the audible click when the pen makes contact with the desk supplies the crisp strike cue.

proxyLocation: right-center of the image, resting on the desk
utilizationMethod: Wrap all fingers around the marker’s barrel near its cap so the capped tip extends forward like a miniature hammer head. The marker is slightly heavier at the ink reservoir end, giving a hint of top weight. Users can practice controlled wrist snaps and feel the sudden resistance when the capped tip taps the table, echoing the precise strikes used when driving small tacks.

physicalObject: closed dark gray notebook or laptop
proxyLocation: bottom-left of the image, flat on the desk surface
utilizationMethod: Slide one hand underneath to grasp a single corner while the rest of the notebook hangs below the fist. The bulk of the notebook supplies noticeable mass, so lifting then swinging it downward gives strong inertial pull similar to a sledge-hammer action. Bringing the notebook’s flat edge to meet the desk produces a solid, vibration-rich impact through the rigid cover back into the user’s hand.

proxyLocation: top-right of the image, partly curled upward
utilizationMethod: Hold the sheet by one corner and snap the wrist so the free-hanging paper slaps against the desk. The sudden air resistance followed by the crisp paper-on-surface slap provides a light version of the hammer’s acceleration and abrupt stop, useful for practicing high-speed swing timing even though the mass is minimal.

proxyLocation: center-left of the desk, sitting upright like a small mound
utilizationMethod: Place the index finger pad on the peak of the crumpled tissue and press straight down until it flattens. The folds compress roughly 3–5 cm before the table stops further motion, giving progressive resistance that loosely mimics the spring travel of the emergency button; releasing the finger lets the paper re-expand, pushing the finger back up.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: Pressing the button to trigger critical actions
virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: The red cap responds to downward pressure by traveling vertically into the base assembly. The travel distance is about 4cm. Users should feel progressive compression resistance.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Interaction is a momentary, downward press using the pad of the index finger (occasionally palm or fist for an emergency-style slam). The user positions the finger above the center of the 15 cm-wide red cap, then applies vertical force. The button travels approximately 4 cm before a hard mechanical stop. During travel, a progressively stiff spring resistance is felt, followed by a tactile click that signals actuation. Upon release, the spring returns the cap to its original height, pushing the user’s finger upward. Typical contact duration is under one second for a tap; sustained presses may occur when holding the action. The surrounding black bezel serves as a visual and physical guide, preventing lateral slip of the finger.

utilizationMethod: Rest the box flat on the desk and press the palm or finger onto the center of the cardboard lid. The lid flexes downward several millimeters and the tissues inside compress further, offering a cushioned spring feel. A firm cardboard stop is felt at the end of travel, then the lid rebounds, simulating a larger, full-hand "slam" on the virtual red button.

proxyLocation: upper-center area, lying horizontally across the paper edge
utilizationMethod: Hold the pen vertically on the desk with the clicker end up. Repeatedly depress the clicker with the thumb or index finger. The built-in spring delivers clear downward travel, increasing resistance and a crisp mechanical click at full depression, followed by an automatic return—closely matching the tactile feedback of the red push-button.

proxyLocation: right-center of the scene, adjacent to the notebook edge
utilizationMethod: Stand the marker vertically on its capped tip. Press down on the opposite end with a fingertip so the felt nib and cap padding compress slightly against the desk (about 2–3 mm) before a hard stop. The small give and rebound provide a mini spring sensation suitable for light, rapid button taps.

proxyLocation: bottom-left portion of the image, resting flat
utilizationMethod: Use the broad, flat cover as an unyielding target for an emergency-style hit: slam the palm or fist onto the center of the notebook to recreate the forceful strike sometimes used on a large red button. Although there is no vertical travel, the solid impact and audible thud reinforce the decisive action characteristic of a critical push.

proxyLocation: top-right, draped over the desk edge
utilizationMethod: Slide the sheet so half of it hangs off the desk, creating unsupported space beneath. Press the fingertip onto the overhanging center area and push downward about 4 cm until the paper becomes taut, then meets the hard edge of the desk as a stop. The gradual sag followed by a firm stop imitates the travel and termination of the virtual button; releasing the finger lets the sheet spring back to flat, giving a light rebound.
